data, online privacy, and electronic communications","phrases":["I do not consent to a search of my phone or devices.","I do not consent to providing passwords or unlocking my device.","Do you have a warrant?","I want to speak to a lawyer.","Please document what data you are requesting and under what authority."],"rights":[{"title":"Right to Encrypt Communications","description":"You have the right to use encryption tools to protect your communications and data. Law enforcement cannot force you to decrypt your devices or provide passwords without a warrant. The government cannot ban encryption or mandate backdoors that weaken security for everyone.","source":"1st Amendment (free speech); 5th Amendment (self-incrimination)","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Consumer Privacy Act protects encrypted data; strong stance against encryption backdoors"},{"state":"NY","note":"Attempted encryption mandate for phones failed; right to encryption remains protected"}]},{"title":"Right Against Unreasonable Digital Searches","description":"Under the Fourth Amendment, police generally need a warrant to search your cell phone, computer, or other digital devices, even if you are arrested. The Supreme Court in Carpenter v. US (2018) also ruled that warrantless access to historical cell site location data violates the Fourth Amendment.","source":"4th Amendment; Riley v. California (2014); Carpenter v. US (2018)","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Electronic Communications Privacy Act (CalECPA) requires warrant for digital searches; stronger than federal law"},{"state":"NY","note":"Strong protections for digital devices; warrant required for most phone/computer searches"},{"state":"TX","note":"Follows Riley and Carpenter; some exceptions for exigent circumstances"},{"state":"FL","note":"Generally requires warrant for device searches; border searches have different rules"}]},{"title":"Right to Anonymous Speech Online","description":"The First Amendment protects your right to speak anonymously online. You can use pseudonyms and privacy tools to protect your identity. However, this right is not absoluteâ€”courts can compel disclosure in certain cases, such as defamation lawsuits or criminal investigations.","source":"1st Amendment; McIntyre v. Ohio Elections Commission (1995)","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Strong protections for anonymous speech; high bar for unmasking anonymous speakers"},{"state":"NY","note":"Courts apply rigorous standard before forcing disclosure of anonymous online speakers"}]},{"title":"Right to Access Your Data","description":"Many state laws give you the right to know what personal data companies collect about you and to request a copy of that data. Under laws like the California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA), you can also request deletion of your data and opt out of its sale.","source":"State Consumer Privacy Laws (CCPA, CPA, CTDPA, etc.)","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"CCPA/CPRA: Right to know, delete, correct, and opt out of sale/sharing of personal information"},{"state":"NY","note":"SHIELD Act requires data security; proposed NYPA would add comprehensive consumer rights"},{"state":"TX","note":"No comprehensive privacy law yet; sector-specific protections for health/financial data"},{"state":"UT","note":"Utah Consumer Privacy Act gives rights to access, delete, and opt out of targeted ads"},{"state":"FL","note":"Digital Rights Act proposed but not yet passed; limited protections currently"}]},{"title":"Right to Delete Accounts and Data","description":"You generally have the right to delete your online accounts and request that companies delete your personal data. Some platforms make this difficult, but many states now require companies to provide straightforward deletion mechanisms. Be aware that some data may be retained for legal or security purposes.","source":"State Privacy Laws; Platform Terms of Service","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"CCPA grants right to deletion; companies must provide clear deletion mechanisms"},{"state":"NY","note":"No comprehensive deletion law yet; sector-specific deletion rights in certain industries"},{"state":"TX","note":"Limited deletion rights; varies by service type"},{"state":"UT","note":"UCPA grants right to delete personal data collected from consumers"}]}]},"availableStates":["CA","FL","NY","TX","UT"]}]}],"$L4"]}],null,"$L5"]}],"loading":null,"isPartial":false}
